description: Galaxia is an arcade style shooter. You control a spaceship and need to earn as many points as possible by shooting the various enemies that appear on the screen. Unlike many similar games (such as Demon Attack or Phoenix) your ship can move about the entire screen and is not limited to horizontal only movement. On each level there is a timer; if time runs out and you haven't finished destroying all of the enemies, the next level will begin, however all of the remaining enemies from the previous level will remain on the screen (so you now have two sets of enemies to destroy at once). There are many different types of enemies to destroy which become faster and more numerous as the levels progress.
title: Galaxia

description: You have been imprisoned by the Garrintrots in the mountain stronghold of Mount Drash. There are 15 levels of tunnels within the mountain, and you must find the exit in each one to escape. Some levels have gems which must be collected before you are allowed to leave. Along the way you will encounter a variety of enemy creatures which will need to be defeated in combat. Only released for the VIC-20, it is a simple maze game with some monster battles, and very little connection to the other games in the series.

sample_screenshots.caption: A few choices of direction to take, and some enemies wandering about
Attacking a gremlin; hopefully I'm winning...

title: Ultima: Escape from Mt. Drash

description: In Pharaoh's Tomb players take the role of an unnamed adventurer, whose objective is to find the four parts of the Pharaoh's key and enter the magical triangle of the gods. The tomb contains many rooms that need to be explored to find the key parts. You're not alone though, the tomb is full of hostile creatures, including lizards, bats and spiders. All these creatures inflict wounds; take too much damage and you're dead. To survive in the tomb, you'll need food, which you can find scattered around the tomb. It also has a fair share of traps, so you have to be careful unless you want to be buried in sand.
title: Pharaoh's Tomb

description: In Riddle of the Sphinx the player must find his way through a maze to gain access to the Sphinx' tomb and answer the riddle to get the Treasure of the Sphinx. That's not as easy as it sounds though. To enter the tomb 500 units of treasure needs to be collected. Treasure is gained by doing various tasks that you will randomly be assigned as you make your way through the maze. These tasks are mini games of different kinds. Some are action based and some only depend on luck. Examples of tasks are surviving a earthquake, avoid being run over by camels, and running away from snakes. Fail with three tasks and it's game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: Guess the wrong number and the room will shrink until you are crushed by the walls.
Stay away from snakes for 30 seconds to get treasure.

title: Riddle of the Sphinx

description: When Tetris first appeared, the VIC-20 was already commercially dead, and it didn't receive an official port. In 2002, one version was developed for the annual Minigame compo, a coding competition with strict size targets. The 1 kilobyte large Zapactris (taking its name from programmer Anders "Zapac" Carlsson) is a fairly faithful replica of the original, albeit without the additions of some Tetris variants, such as bonus points for eliminating multiple lines, etc.

sample_screenshots.caption: Restraining the screen size allows some extra compact programming tricks

title: Zapactris

description: A 1-kilobyte game (coded for the MiniGame Compo coding contest) for the unexpanded VIC-20, Jewels 20 is a puzzle game based on the same concept as Bejeweled. You have two minutes to eliminate as many jewels as possible from the playfield by swapping a pair of jewels around, forming a row of three or more of the same colour. Swapping pairs is only possible if the swap will result in same-colored rows. As the rows are formed, they disappear, and the jewels above fall down, with more coming in from above, making this an endless game were it not for the time limit. For each eliminated jewel, you score 10 points, with bonus points given for arranging Puyo Puyo-style chain reactions.
title: Jewels 20

description:
VIQ-Bert is perhaps not the first, or even the best variation on Q*Bert for the VIC-20, but it is by far the smallest, weighing in at under a single kilobyte (programmed for the 2002 edition of the MiniGame Compo coding contest).

As in the original Q*Bert, the player moves on a 3D pyramid, coloring the fields of the pyramid as he/she/it moves. Coloring all tiles clears the level. This would be easy were it not for the enemies moving around in haphazard patterns on the same pyramid. Unlike the original Q*Bert enemies, they don't change back the color of the game tiles, but contact is deadly. Another way to die is to fall off the pyramid. Later levels require coloring the same squares multiple times, and even later, you cannot pass the same square twice without changing the color back, so a strategy element is introduced.

sample_screenshots.caption: Second level has two tile colours
On the third level, you can't pass the same tile twice

title: VIQ-Bert

description:
A simple but technically accomplished game for the VIC-20, Dragonwing puts you in a spaceship flying through a system of caves at a very fast pace. As you move along, and try not to crash into the undulating cave walls, you expend fuel, and must pick up new fuel supplies from the cave floor. Unlike Scramble or Super Cobra, flying through the caves is not easy, even though they are not guarded by missile silos. Since your vehicle is not a helicopter, but a rocket, you fly through the caves at a very fast pace and without stopping. The laws of gravity an inertia mean that you can't adjust your pace with pixel precision. Instead, your altitude must be consistently altered so that you do not crash into the ground, while you have to compensate your maneuvers so as not to crash into the ceiling.

Programmed in 2002, Dragonwing has little in common with the VIC-20 games of twenty years earlier, what with multicolor sprites, smooth fast scrolling and a breakbeat soundtrack played throughout the game, despite running on an unexpanded VIC-20.

sample_screenshots.caption: The block with an F contains fuel

title: Dragonwing

description:
You are the pilot of the fastest starship in the galaxy armed with dual anti-gravity thrusters and a powerful laser cannon that will zap any enemy force this side of Betelgeuse.

You have to move through a radioactive asteroid belt, zapping the Imperial Star Destroyers.

To complete the phase you are confronted by the evil Deranged Mutoids.

sample_screenshots.caption: Lot's of obstacles heading your way...

title: Neutron Zapper

description: The name "Guardian" sounds like a euphemism for "Defender", and indeed there are similarities. This is a side-scrolling shooter with the same kind of space ship, the same kind of aliens and the same kind of landscape as Defender, but without all the technicalities of that game. You don't rescue humans, and the scroll is forced in one direction. You simply have to shoot your way through hordes of aliens, with more and more of them occupying the screen as you progress. The aliens are mostly fixed in their position, but will sometimes move a step up or down to get in your way. As you progress further, additional alien types are introduced.

sample_screenshots.caption: A new type of alien enters the game

title: Guardian

description:
Scram 20 is a Scramble clone for the VIC-20.

Fly a small spaceship through a system of caves, guarded by missiles. The player has a gun to shoot down airborne targets and bombs to bomb ground installations. Fuel supply is constantly counting down, so the player must also bomb any fuel containers found on the ground. Later on, the game introduces constant airborne enemies, in addition to the ground-to-air missiles. Scram 20 utilities a character-based scroll, which means that it scrolls quickly, but in increments of 8 pixels.

sample_screenshots.caption: Bomb the ones marked with an F for fuel

title: Scram 20

description: VIC Scramble is another Scramble game for the VIC-20, but with some alterations that make it stand out. As usual, you fly with a ship through a system of caves, but this cave lacks the usual roof. You shoot or drop bombs at the usual missiles, saucers and fuel pods, but in this version, you don't shoot and bomb simultaneously. Bombs are released by pulling back on the joystick with the fire button pressed. Of course, this means that you can't go back and forth as usual, instead your ship is glued to the back of the screen. While the scrolling is forced, pushing forward makes it speed up, so that you can fly away from missiles and other threats. As you go deeper into the caves, the border colour changes.

sample_screenshots.caption: A thin passage, watch out for the missiles

title: VIC Scramble

description: Skramble is another Scramble clone, this time from Rabbit Software. You fly above a coarse landscape filled with missiles, factories and fuel supplies. Bomb the fuel supplies in order to refill your own fuel, and bomb the rest for points. The missiles are inactive at the beginning, but after a while, they start to launch in order to intercept you. After that, the mountainous landscape turns into a cave, with thin passages that must be navigated while spider-like things fly in your path. You have only one life, after that it is game over for you.

sample_screenshots.caption: After the into melody, you enter the game

title: Skramble

description: Kwazy Kwaks is a simple shooting gallery game spiced up with a certain duck flavour, obviously inspired by UPL's Carnival. You have a gun mounted at the bottom of the screen. Above are three rows of targets moving around. The targets consist of rabbits, owls, duck and boxes with numbers. You move your gun left and right in order to hit the targets, and you earn more scores for hitting those on the higher rows. You have a limited amount of bullets, but hitting the numbered boxes add more to your arsenal. While the rabbits and owls require just one hit, the ducks will change colours several times before being eliminated. When only five targets remain, the screen changes colour and they must be hit before they leave the screen forever. As you progress, the speed is elevated.
title: Kwazy Kwaks

description: Krell is a Space Invaders clone with a twist. You don't have any barriers for protection against the enemy formations, instead you have a barrier above them. This barrier protects seven space aliens from a lone yellow invader who patrols the upper portion of the screen. Shoot down the invader formation without hitting the barrier, or you might end up hitting the trapped aliens. When all the white aliens are dead, it's game over time, and that is also the case when you are killed.

sample_screenshots.caption: The last surviving white alien is killed

title: Krell

description:
Quadrant takes place on the planet of Synlac, that is attacked by aliens. The planet is split into four quadrants, each patrolled by a volunteer. One of these is Boris, the player character, who controls the Northern Quadrant. Now he must defend the planet from the aliens.

You take control of Boris who is running on the ground. Above are the flying aliens swarming around him. At the same time as he has to avoid being hit by alien fire, he also has to jump over the craters that appear in the terrain. The game contains four skill levels. If Boris survives all eight waves of aliens he will advance to the next level which represents another quadrant of the planet. For each killed alien he will be awarded 50 points. The points increase with every level. The screen constantly scrolls from left to right and the player can choose to increase or decrease the speed of Boris.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting out. Being attacked by aliens from above.
More and more aliens as time goes.

title: Quadrant

description:
Fire Galaxy is a clone of Konami's Scramble, with pieces of its follow-up Super Cobra added.

The premise is the same as in the original: Fly into a side-scrolling cavern system and shoot everything that moves, while keeping an eye on your fuel level. Drop bombs on fuel silos to avoid crashing. Early enemies are rockets launching from the ground while shooting at you, followed by enemies hovering around in the air, missiles flying fast in your direction, aliens bouncing up and down in your path, a fleet of spaceships and swarms of aliens.

Another enemy is the landscape itself. Avoid crashing into the walls of the levels during evasive manoeuvres. The landscape never really narrows down like in so many other scramble clones, but instead there are formations like stalactites and stalagmites, much like in Super Cobra. The aliens regenerate unless you pound them repeatedly.

Fire Galaxy uses a character based scroller, scrolling in 8-pixel increments, with big sprites on a large screen.

sample_screenshots.caption: The small openings are guarded by fast little aliens
The flashing logo scrolls onto the screen

title: Fire Galaxy

description: ViColumn is, as one might guess, a re-implementation of Sega's Columns for the VIC-20. Blocks of three vertically arranged colours, out of a pallette of four, come dropping down from above, and must be placed on the bottom or on top of another block. By pressing fire, you can rotate the colours inside the block so as to fit in with the colours of other blocks already placed on the screen. If three or more adjacent blocks have the same colour on a row or column, that colour block is eliminated, making room for more blocks. Carefully laying down the blocks can lead to chain reactions. Unlike the original Columns, though, this implementation does not recognise diagonal colour combinations.

sample_screenshots.caption: Oh no, it doesn't support diagonals!

title: ViColumn

description:
After Zapactris, comes a more fully featured Tetris for the VIC-20. This implementation, making fuller use of the VIC's memory, has proper calculation of points, as well as a brick wall getting in the way of your blocks, though it can be turned off.

This game has later on been expanded as a collaborative effort into Tetris Deluxe.

sample_screenshots.caption: The wall can only be destroyed through a lot of effort
Starting the game. Note the brick wall

title: Tetris

description:
Based on Nippur72's Tetris for the VIC-20, the Deluxe version introduces a lot of new features:

The brick wall is off by default, and no longer random, there is a high score display, colours are changed around and graphics changed, new scoring and a soundtrack, taken from the Game Boy Tetris.
title: Tetris Deluxe

description: Sport Sport is a primitive joystick-waggler, only you (and up to three mates) waggle the keyboard instead. Four runners; Red, Blue, Afro and Nude, run a distance ranging from 100 to 1 500 metres by each pushing a key in one of the corners of the keyboard.
title: Sport Sport

description: Blue Star is a game for the unexpanded VIC-20 in a similar vein to other open-ended platform games like Metroid, the newer Castlevania games or Cave Story. Infiltrate the alien base and take out the CPU! Find equipment along the way to add to your abilities; a jet pack to let you double jump, a rocket launcher to let you launch rockets, and more.

sample_screenshots.caption: Blue Star for Unexpanded VIC-20 gameplay

title: Blue Star

description:
Skramble! is a version of Scramble for the VIC-20 by Terminal Software. The player has to direct a ship in a cavernous system. The goal is to reach the finish and avoid or shoot missiles, helicopters and other enemies. The player can fly in all directions but has to follow the scrolling to the right. It's possible to shoot, drop bombs and fill the fuel by hitting an oil tank.

This time the background color is white with black rocks.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting position. A melody is playing here.
Dropping a bomb, but missing the oil tank
A creature is coming, while bombing a helicopter and shooting an oil tank.

title: Skramble!

description:
This is a book of instructions for numerous type-in BASIC games:

  • Monster Maze -- like a summarized Pac-Man, eating dots in a maze avoiding monsters, which can temporarily be eaten after eating cherries.
  • Hyperspace Escape -- an Asteroids clone
  • Gunfight -- "Outshoot the fastest draw in town, VIC". Three buttons regulate four functions: moving up and down, shooting and dodging.
  • Scramble -- a game of aerial bombardment
  • Alien Marauders -- likely a Space Invaders clone
  • Airplane -- "Attempt to land your passengers safely on the runway at La Guardia Airport." A simulation of landing an airplane consulting only cockpit instrumentation. "Good luck. It may take practice to land correctly. I can't!"
  • Marathon -- the player places bets on one of three athletes, then the computer simulates a foot race between and lets the player know how their financial speculation turned out. "The game continues until you are broke or you break the bank."
  • Wizard (or Computer Wizard) -- a "Simon-says" iterative song-repeating game
  • Tail Gunner -- a gunsights-aiming game (using the almost-standard WADX control keys)
  • Astro Wars -- also sounds very Space Invaders-y. Only so many distinguishing characteristics can be gleaned by eyeballing the source code.
  • Swarm -- a game about intercepting the trajectory of enemy spacecraft on a collision course
  • 3-D Maze -- wherein the player attempts to set a speed record for plotting a course to maze cell #25, in an eerie textmode first-person perspective.
  • Brands Hatch -- a topdown car racing simulation whose goal is primarily to avoid colliding with other vehicles or the sides of the road.
  • Lightning Bolt -- a somewhat conceptually abstract game, the player here attempts to intercept the tip of a descending lightning bolt with a cursor-drawn wall without touching the bolt's sides.
  • Space Birds -- a Space Invaders-y top-down space shooter with a backstory almost as long as the source code listing.
  • Arkenstone -- an explicitly Tolkien-derived early text adventure game with an unusual text parser, accepting input of strings up to nine words long one[enter]word[enter]at[enter]a[enter]time[enter][enter].
  • Gomoku -- the Asian parlour game whose goal is getting five stones in a row. "WARNING: This program takes a few minutes to make its move."
  • Lunar Lander -- a simple conversion apparently unconstrained by fuel limitations.
  • Earth Defense -- a Missile Command clone.
  • Nightmare Castle -- the description is peculiarly abstract ("THE ROOM is a strange place. All sorts of weird things happen, but you'll have to find out what yourself") but the fundamentals seem straightforward enough: navigating a graphical maze, locating and retrieving a treasure, and avoiding being eaten by a monster.
  • Checkers -- a conversion of the board game. Input is via board coordinates.
  • Dambuster -- from the sounds of things, a Zaxxon-like challenge to line up the player's spaceship with a supposedly 3D environment and fire the player's weapon at the right moment.
  • Smash -- a paddle-and-ball game.
  • Dogfight -- a daredevil game of aerial duelling.
  • Night Raid -- an aerial bombing simulation
  • Tank Battle -- a top-down tank duelling game, spiced up with mines and fuel drums.
  • Danger Star -- a simulation of Star Wars' Death Star trench-flying feat.
  • Reversi -- a conversion of the board game ("You'll find the VIC plays slowly, but remarkably well." Great, the worst of both worlds!)
  • Fruit Machine -- a slot-machine gambling simulator.
  • Dr Watson -- a "guess what number the computer is thinking" game, giving "too high" and "too low" feedback.
  • Dr Audio -- Dr Watson with proportional sound feedback to let the player know how close they are.
  • Tight Squeeze -- a gambling game.
  • Time Guardian -- the player navigates between the six sectors of each of six quadrants (sextants?) in search of the six parts of the key of Chronos.
  • Long John Silver -- a "find the buried treasure" game of simplified Battleship with a one-cell treasure on a 10x10 cell map.
  • Robot Nim -- A conversion of the parlour game Nim.
  • Victim (or VICtim) -- another simulated race.
  • Evolution -- Conway's Game of LIFE.
  • Vic-et-un -- Blackjack with dice.
  • Hangman -- a two-player-only version of the word-guessing game.
  • Codebreaker -- a version of Mastermind.
  • Fairway -- a golf simulator.
  • Jelly Bean Space Swarm -- the player must navigate a space ship through some crudely rendered asteroids.
  • Zauper Attack -- the player must zap the aliens before they are eaten by the Zaupers.
  • Superbowl -- a 10-pin bowling simulator.
  • Zombie Island -- wherein the player attempts to drown the zombies by situating zombie-drowning swamp patches between himself and them.
  • Motorcycle Jump -- a daredevil motorcyclist game (playing as "Evil K."), calculating the speed at which to approach a ramp to clear an arbitrary number of double-decker buses... without overdriving and flipping upside-down!
  • Traffic Jam -- a top-down simulation of piloting a car to a parking spot with moving obstacles (presumably, other vehicles on the road.)
  • Hangman 11 -- a one-player version of the word-guessing game, which the computer stocks with a limited vocabulary.
  • Antihang -- the computer plays Hangman and guesses the player's word.
  • Treacle Balls -- a game of logic and deduction.
  • Craps -- the dice gambling game.
  • Caveman -- challenging the Cro-magnon player to survive in a treasure-and-trap-filled cave complex.
  • Tranquility Base -- Lunar Lander again, this time tracking fuel use.
  • Lodestar/3-D Maze -- attempt to locate a lodestar in a maze. (The 3-D aspect is left as an exercise for the reader. Really!)
  • Monza -- the computer guesses a number the player is thinking of.
  • Mento -- "another mathematical mind-reading wizard."
  • Flip -- a geometrical puzzle played on a 3x3 grid.
  • Colormind -- "This, as you've probably guessed, is a color version of Mastermind."
  • Cannibal Charlie -- a delicious ecological simulation challenging players to achieve a high score by finding the most stable equilibrium between populations of cannibals and explorers.
  • Noughts and Crosses -- or Tic-Tac-Toe to the non-Brits in the room.
  • Speedway -- a top-down solo racing simulation played for longevity.
  • Battle -- a new board game similar to Checkers.
  • Reverse -- a thrilling "game" about setting numerical sequences in order.
  • Space Fighter -- a space combat game.
  • Engulf -- the player avoids as long as possible being surrounded by regularly-appearing colored blocks.
  • Reaction -- a simple test of the player's reflexes.
  • Spacetrek -- the player defends a 10x10 grid from aliens as long as their ship's energy levels hold out.
  • Quack -- a target-shooting game.
  • Magic Square -- filling in numbers to make every cross-section of the 3x3 grid add up to the same sum.
  • Simon -- the player repeats computer-generated numerical sequences of increasing length.
  • Roulette -- a simulation of the casino game.

Additionally, the book contains listings for the following, non-game programs:

  • Night on a Wild Mountain -- a non-interactive light and sound demo, in the same vein as two Symphony for a Melancholic Computer programs included and one entitled Sepulcher Organ.
  • Superpoet -- a non-interactive poetry generator.
  • Vincent Van Vic -- a paint program.
  • Monte Carlo Molecule -- this program randomly plots a course between points on a cube.
  • Zodiac Fortune Teller -- lives up to its name.
  • Biorhythms -- a calculator of physical, mental and emotional cycles.
  • Billboard -- a program to display large text on the screen.
title: ZAP! POW! BOOM! Arcade Games for the Vic-20

description:
Garden Wars is a fast paced, single-screen 8-way maze shooter, similar to Berzerk. Your goal? Earn as many points as possible by shooting and collecting stuff in a static, fixed-screen maze.

However, the game is original due to the variety of on-screen stuff. There are some monsters which you need to shoot, and which will kill you. There are flashing items you need to pick up (for points only); if you accidentally shoot them (which will happen due to the speed of the game), they will disappear and reappear elsewhere. Finally, there are small yellow spider eggs which, if not destroyed, will hatch small yellow spiders, and these spiders will, if not destroyed, finally evolve into blue spiders, which you cannot destroy, only paralyze for a while.

sample_screenshots.caption: Collect the gold bars, shoot the enemies and be careful!

title: Garden Wars

description: Mole Attack is one of the earliest computerized Whac-a-Mole variants. Gameplay should be clear: Moles randomly pop out of several holes (arranged in a 3x3 grid), and you can hit them using the right keyboard key (one for each hole). The sooner you hit the mole's head, the more points you get -- but if you hit the mole's buttocks (yes, them buggers sometimes pop up that way), you lose points. After 60 seconds, the game ends and your score is shown.

sample_screenshots.caption: Moles will start to appear at the various locations.
Many moles can be on screen at once.
When the timer runs out it's game over.

title: Mole Attack

description:
Menagerie is a clone of the game Frogger, with an original theme however. You play a flea whose goal is to cross full of moving animals from the bottom to the upper border. On the lower half, you have to evade several flea-eating animals; on the upper screen, the situation is reversed: you suck the animals' blood and need to jump from one animal to the other. On the upper border, you need to jump into one of three flea-nests to fulfill your destiny.

The game features ten difficulty levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: On the second half of the screen you need to ride on the backs of the animals.
Two bugs are safe, only one more to go to complete the level.
You have to be very careful with your timing to get the bugs home.

title: Menagerie

description: Another VIC in the Wall is a simple Breakout variant. The player uses a paddle at the bottom of the screen to reflect a ball that bounces around the screen. The screen is constantly being filled with bricks and the idea is to destroy these by hitting them with the ball. If the ball goes past the paddle the player loses a life. He has three lives in total. The goal is simply to get as many points as possible. There is no end to it as new bricks are continuously added to the screen. The game is written in machine code and can be played with either keyboard or joystick.

sample_screenshots.caption: After the blue bricks come the yellow

title: Another VIC in the Wall

description: Getting lost is what players of Get Lost! should avoid doing. Instead they should find their way out of a complicated maze. The objective is to move from top left to the bottom right corner of the maze. This should be done in as few moves as possible. There are a dozen mazes in the game and they are randomly chosen at start up. The game features six levels of difficulty. On the easier levels the player is presented with both a top down perspective and a first person perspective of the maze. On the more difficult levels the top down view is disabled and the player has to make his way through the maze with only the first person view. The game is played with keyboard by simply inputting the commands, left, right and forward.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting out in the top left corner
A level higher - should be a bit more complicated

title: Get Lost!

description: In King Tut the player takes the role of Archie, a lion-hearted explorer who has entered the tomb of Tutankhamun, the Egyptian pharaoh. In his quest for gold and glory he has to traverse the maze like corridors of the tomb until he finds the famed golden death mask. The game is played from a side view. At the start the player has a good view of his surroundings and can locate the position of the mask. However, the player's lamp is not reliable and will go out after a short time. The tomb will then become shrouded in darkness and the player will only be able to see what he is next to. So thereby the game gets a lot harder if the player is too slow. The player is not alone in the tomb. He has to watch out for it's guardians (mummies, scorpions, spiders and snakes) who will instantly kill him when he gets to close. When completing the game the player gets a score based on how much gold he collects.

sample_screenshots.caption: Gold is scattered throughout the tomb
Face to face with a poisonous snake
Spiders might not look like much but they are as lethal as the rest of the guardians
Getting a score on completion - but only if you actually complete it, if you die you get zero

title: King Tut

description: In Vic-torian Follies: Adv. 1 - Seaquest the player has to retrieve lost treasure from the bottom of the ocean. The player has a side view of the ocean and can move his ship, The Victorian Rose, left and right along the surface. In his search for treasure he uses a diving bell which can be moved up and down. The treasure is not visible from the start and the player has to use the bell to find it. It beeps when it's getting close. When the treasure is found the screen flashes and the bell automatically picks it up. After that it only has to be pulled up to the ship. Due to the dangers of the sea this might not be as easy as it sounds. Serpents swim around in the ocean and the player has be careful so they don't swim into the bell and its cable. If it hits the bell and the crew inside will be lost. Another problem is the storms which appear in the sky at times. When the clouds are above the ship it won't be able to move.

sample_screenshots.caption: Sometimes you're not as lucky - a serpent

title: Vic-torian Follies: Adv. 1 - Seaquest

description: Invaders Addition is an educational game where the player has to defend earth from an alien invasion. This is done by doing math. The player controls a gun at the bottom of the screen. From the top alien saucers will appear and move towards the player. On the saucer is an addition problem that the player has to figure out. If he types the right answer the alien will be shot down and another will appear. Input the wrong number and the alien will continue towards the player. It's game over when the alien reaches the player. The player wins if he manages to defend earth for two minutes. Before the game the player can choose a difficulty level. In the harder difficulties the aliens move faster and the problems are harder.
title: Invaders Addition

description: In Blue Meanies From Outer Space the player is in charge of defending a starbase that is being attacked by these blue little cuboid creatures. To do this he uses six laser guns, three on each of the base's sidewalls. The meanies fall from the sky and the player has to shoot them down before they can do any damage to the base. Using the lasers cost energy and when the energy is out the weapons won't work. At times supply ships land with more energy. It's important to not shoot these down as it leads to a reduction of points. To fix the holes caused by the meanies the player can use a repair robot. This however costs a large amount of energy.
title: Blue Meanies From Outer Space

description:
In the last few years of the 19th century many young adventurers travel to Africa in search of diamonds. One such young man is Englishman Ricky Rockman who aims to dig his way through the mines and return home with plenty of riches. It's not an easy job though. Not only has he watch out for falling boulders but also the vile creatures that patrol the mines.

Rockman is a Boulder Dash variant. The aim of the game is to collect all the diamonds for each level. Throughout the levels are also boulders and monsters that wander around. Boulders follow the laws of gravity and fall down when the player digs a hole below them. The player then has to be quick or he might be crushed by them. Boulders can also be used to kill the monsters. When all diamonds in a level has been collected a gate leading to the next will open. The player has three lives and they will be used if he comes into contact with a monster or is crushed by a boulder. There is also a time limit.
title: Rockman

description: In Bullet the player takes the role of a bank robber who has the chance to rob four banks. The game consists of two parts. The first part is a clone of Head On. The player races his car through a maze consisting of three lanes and has to pick up all the coins that are scattered around. In the opposite direction comes a police car that the player has to avoid crashing into. Once all coins have been collected he gets the chance to rob the bank. This is the second part of the game and is most reminiscent of a snake game. The banks appear on the screen one at a time and the player has to drive over them. At the same time the car leave a trail that the player has to avoid crashing into. The player has four lives to complete his task.
title: Bullet

description:
Earth is once again threatened by an alien invasion. The last remaining radio tower is under attack and without it the skilled Sidewinder Commandos won't stand a chance against the invaders. The Sidewinder Commandos is the last remaining helicopter force and the player is one of them. The aliens are programmed to destroy the player so he has to do his uttermost to defeat them.

Sidewinder is a Defender variant. The player takes control of a helicopter and can fly above the planet's surface in any direction. Around him he will find countless of aliens that he has to shoot down or else he will likely meet an early death. The player's objective is to defend a number of radio towers. The player has three lives at start and by every 3000 points he earns a new one. There are a number of different enemies including one that suddenly appears on the screen and then goes right at the player. Before the game the player can choose between ten difficulty levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: These green things are a bit tricky
Are these some kind of space eels?

title: Sidewinder

description: Dodge Cars is a simple racing game. The game is viewed from a top down perspective and the player races down a road consisting of five lanes. From the opposite direction comes countless cars and the aim is to drive as far as possible without crashing. The cars move automatically forward at a steady pace and all the player has to do is to move right or left between the lanes. The player gets a score based on how far down the freeway he or she gets. The game is controlled with a joystick.

sample_screenshots.caption: I have to move between the lanes to avoid a crash

title: Dodge Cars

description: In Money Wars the player takes the role of a robber that has to retrieve and deliver bags of money without getting shot. The game is viewed from a side perspective. The player starts at the left side and has to move across the screen to the money bag that lies on the right side and then return to his starting position. From the top deadly arrows are shot towards him and these he has to dodge or he will lose a life. To his help he has three brick barricades that he can hide behind. He can't hide too long though as the barricades take damage from the arrows and will after a while be gone. The player can use two special functions. One that increases speed and one that creates a force field that destroys arrows. These cost energy and the player is awarded bonus points for the amount of energy he has left. When a bag of money has been delivered another one appears and the game goes on until the player has lost all of his three lives. For every fifth money bag delivered the player progresses to a new level.
title: Money Wars

description: Terraguard is a fixed screen shoot 'em up similar to Moon Cresta and Phoenix. The player controls their ship down the base line and has to shoot at the aliens above them. There are three aliens for each stage and the player has to shoot them all down to move on to the next stage. At the same time, the aliens have a ship that tries to land on the surface. To stop it from doing this, the player has to be quick in destroying the aliens. Else the player will be killed by the ship's tractor beam. The player has three lives and earns a new one when scoring 1000 points. There are three different kinds of aliens: jeeby-jeebys, eyes and mouths. Each alien gives a different score depending on how hard they are to take down.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level completed - the screen scrolls away

title: Terraguard

description: Scorpion is a clone of Centipede for the VIC-20, but there are a few tweaks. The centipede in Atari's popular game has been replaced by a group of scorpions that make their way down a field of cacti towards the player who must go left or right, shooting at the scorpions to destroy them. Spiders appear and fly across the screen to make your job even harder, and spores drop down, leaving a line of cacti in its path. Shoot both of these for bonus points. Get rid of the scorpions to proceed to the next level. Contact with any one of the creatures will result in a loss of life, and losing all your lives ends the game.
title: Scorpion

description:
Gold Fever! is an action game with platform elements in which the player controls a miner searching for gold. At the beginning of the game the miner is at the uppermost tiers of the mine. Scattered around the five levels of the mine are little piles of gold. The goal is to move towards them and pick them up. To move the miner safely from level to level the player steers him up or down the vertical shafts in the floors. There are complications, such as runaway ore carts, which interfere with the miner's progress by knocking him down. Three collisions and the player is out of miners, ending the game. The miner will be able to jump over the obstructions if the player times the jumps perfectly. This adds from 30 to 40 points to the player's score. If the miner can cross a chasm by running across a boxcar, he earns another 20 points.

The miner's troubles also include having to jump over a murderous claim jumper who will, from time to time, ambush him. Sometimes it is also necessary to leap over boulders. Moving from one tier to the next before the rocks appear on screen doesn't help the player evade them; they always appear on the same tier as the miner.

Once the miner has collected all the gold on the screen, he can make a run for the exit at the lower left of the screen and begin the process on the next level. Each of the nine levels becomes increasingly difficult as the player proceeds. The miner needs to collect more gold on each succeeding level, the obstructions are faster, and as a result the player must change the timing of the jumps. The oxygen supply is limited, and slow-moving miners tend to suffocate.

sample_screenshots.caption: Navigate the mine, avoid the enemies and gather the gold.

title: Gold Fever!

description:
In Deadly Skies you fly an attack helicopter against an array of military installations and anti-aircraft missile sites. Joystick controls allow you to move your chopper to track the targets below or to avoid the rapidly increasing volleys of fire from all around you.

The obstacles you must overcome are asteroids, smart bombs, anti-aircraft missiles and even UFOs that are working hard to destroy you because you have been assigned to take out their missile bases.

As you improve and destroy the targets on the ground, the game moves you up to a higher level of intensity. On some of the levels, you encounter mostly smart bombs. More than a dozen can be in the air at a time. You will be forced to spend most of your time in evasion, unable to aim your bombs. Rockets are fired at you by in heavy numbers, several volleys at a time. With the skies packed with missiles, you will find it hard to thread a safe path, even though they aren't homing in on you.

The reward of reaching the higher levels are the banks of asteroids slicing through the air in deadly clusters. Even though you collect a point for each hit on them, they very effectively block your attack against the targets down below.

At the 17th (out of 32) level of the game, the speed of the game increases twofold, making it twice as dangerous flying, and throwing off the timing you gained in the first 16 levels. By that time, you will most likely have earned reinforcement helicopters to carry on the battle (one for every 10,000 points).

sample_screenshots.caption: You have to bomb the clouds to remove them and then bomb the enemy city.
The sky is full of danger.

title: Deadly Skies

description: Creepy Corridors is a maze game similar to Wizard of Wor, adventurer Sierra Smith has entered the catacombs of Creepy Corridors in search for treasures. The mazes are full of riches but there are also lots of creatures that will do all they can to protect it. That's not enough to stop this adventurer though and it's up to the player to help him out. Each level consists of four diamonds that the player has to pick up. At the same time he has to avoid getting killed by the monsters that wander around the corridors. To his help he has a gun that he can use to shoot the creatures as they get close. Once all the diamonds have been picked up, an exit will open up that takes the player to the next level. The exit will also open when the player has killed all the monsters before collecting the diamonds. The player has four lives at the start of the game and each time he collects all the diamonds of a level he earns an extra one. More and tougher enemies are encountered as the player progresses through the levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level 3 - a new monster is introduced
And seconds later the monsters enter the maze

title: Creepy Corridors

description:
This game is a single player shooter game based on an encounter with a swarm of intergalactic android wasps, bred by an elusive Queen wasp and her trail of mutant eggs. Additionally other entities hunt the player as he contends with this attacking swarm. The Rhizopod and Rhizopus are indestructible creeping viruses that require evasion constantly, and the long thought extinct Dodoclaw is a voracious attacking bird of prey with dangerous talons.

There are 40 levels of increasing difficulty.

Scoring is as follows:

  • Eggs: 1 point each.
  • Queen: 200 points.
  • Dodoclaw: 100, 200, or 300 points.
  • Android Wasp Swarm: 50 points per wasp.
  • Rhizopod and Rhizopus: indestructible.
  • Egg shells: 50 points.

Player awarded an extra man for every 10,000 points.

sample_screenshots.caption: Touch any of the bugs and you lose a life.
The dots on the screen actually impede your movement and direct the flow of the oncoming enemies.

title: Swarm!

description:
Space Phreeks is a single player Galaga style shooter game where the player is faced with arrays of invaders that require destruction to earn points and to survive. The aliens are divided among 5 types: 'Heart attacks', the most powerful and lethal move rapidly for the kill. 'Pearons', which use their maneuverability to protect themselves as they attempt to knick you up and slow you down. 'Energridders' are the midfield powerbacks, brightly colored and easy to see amidst the clutter, will attempt to close in as a group, isolate and destroy you. 'Behindheads' always trail in the rear of the enemy formations, seemingly slow to act, will lull you into danger if they're not dealt with quickly. 'Towelheads' are the peripheral players, constantly harassing you as attempt to fight your way into the clear to face the next wave.

Space Phreeks gives the player 15 levels of combat to work through.

Scoring is very basic: Each enemy killed, of whatever class, will earn you 50 points.
title: Space Phreeks

description: Arachnoid is a fixed screen shoot 'em up where the player takes control of a spider that has to defend its eggs from hostile ants. The game is most similar to Centipede. The ants attack in rows, moving horizontally one line at a time until they get to the player who moves around in the lower sections of the screen. Unlike Centipede there are no obstacles when starting out, but as the player shoots his web at the ants a wall of webbing is created. These causes the ants to change their direction. In addition to ants there are gnats and flies that can carry ants and open up passages in the wall. There are also wasps that moves across the screen at times. The game goes on until the eggs hatch or they have all been taken by the ants. Once the eggs hatch the player moves on to a new and tougher level.

sample_screenshots.caption: It gets crowded after a while
Second level - now these insects are yellow
The eggs are hatching - level completed

title: Arachnoid

description:
Video Mania is a shoot 'em up similar to Robotron. The game is played on a single screen and the player can move and shoot in any direction. Around alien creatures roam and the player has to shoot them down before they collide with him or her. The only defence available is a football-shaped electronic alien zapper that is thrown at the aliens. Unlike Robotron, it's played with only one joystick and therefore the player can only shoot in the direction of movement.

There are three different enemies. The evil eye which bounces off when hitting a wall, the walwoker which climbs walls when they hit and otherwise move in unpredictable ways and the killerbox which always follows the player. Each killed alien is worth 50 points and once all have been killed, a new level is started with a larger amount of enemies. The player starts with three lives and after every 10th level, the player gets a bonus life.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level completed - then some strange cutscene

title: Video Mania

description: Sea Invasion is a Space Invaders variant set in the ocean. The player is a scuba diver who while down on the sea bed is being attacked by different sea creatures. The player moves left and right along the sea bed and has use his spear gun to shoot at the creatures above him while watching out for their projectiles. Some protection can be had from corals but these will disappear as they are hit by projectiles. There are three different sea creatures, octopi, crabs and starfish and the player gets points based on the position of each. Octopi are farthest away from the player and are therefore worth the most points. At times a shark swims across the surface and the player can get a bonus score for shooting it. The game is endless, when all creatures has been killed it all starts over with a new level until the player has lost all his lives.
title: Sea Invasion

description:
Spills & Fills is an educational game whose aim is to develop the skills of proportion, coordination and perception in children ages 6 to 12.

The player's task is to fill beakers with water using the least amount of fill ups and spilling as little water as possible. There are two kinds of beakers, the object beakers that have to be filled and the master beakers that are used to do it. To do so the player controls a crane that allows him to pick up master beakers and fill them with water from a faucet which then can be emptied into the object beakers. The game is completed when all of the object beakers are full. There are two kinds of scores for the player to keep track of, number of fills and the amount of water spilled. There are two different levels of difficulty. On level 1 all object beakers are the same shape but different in size, while on level 2 they differ in both shape and size.

sample_screenshots.caption: And then emptying it into a object beaker

title: Spills & Fills

description: Crater Raider is a multi-screen action game. The object of the game is to destroy a giant asteroid that is on a collision course with the planet Earth. The player must guide Raider Rick over the surface of the asteroid, jumping over craters and avoiding flying meteorites (and aliens, in the later stages). The player starts with three lives and will lose one if Rick falls into a crater or is hit by a flying object. Rick's supply of oxygen is limited, but more oxygen can be obtained by picking up canisters that are strewn about the asteroid's surface. If Rick runs out of oxygen, the game will end. When the 20th screen is reached, a bomb must be dropped in the large crater. Once the bomb is dropped, the player has only three minutes to guide Rick back to his ship before the bomb explodes. If Rick's mission is successful, the player will earn an extra life and proceed to a more difficult asteroid. The game has nine levels of difficulty.

sample_screenshots.caption: Jump to get across the craters.
Caught between a meteor and a crater!
You must cross the crater filled landscape.
Later levels feature alien ships in addition to the meteors.

title: Crater Raider

description:
Cyclon is a space-themed reflex game that is similar to Midway's Space Zap. The object of the game is to survive as long as possible by defending your star base from enemy star cruisers and deadly satellites. The game has 99 levels of difficulty, and the player may begin at any level from 0-10.

The player's star base is located at the center of the screen and enemies firing light missiles will approach from all sides. The star base is armed with lasers that can be fired in all four directions, as well as a limited amount of anti-matter bombs which destroy all on-screen enemies. Shields can also be activated to intercept enemy shots. Firing lasers and using shields will use up energy, and if the player's energy runs out, their star base will explode. If the player does not destroy enemies or intercept their shots, their missiles will inflict damage to the player's star base. Shields will be rendered unusable on any part of the base that is hit by an enemy. The star base will be vaporized if the enemy shots penetrate the reactor at the base's core.

The player starts the game with three bases and will earn an additional one each time a level is completed. Additionally, any extra energy remaining at the end of each round will be converted to extra points. When all of the player's star bases have been lost, the game is over.

sample_screenshots.caption: Move the joystick to shoot in that direction.
Enemy bullets wear down your base.
Using a bomb will destroy all enemies on the screen.
Multiple enemies appear at the same time after a couple of levels.

title: Cyclon

description:
In 3D Maze you're a 'spaceman' who, on a routine trip back from Mars while in orbit around Venus, is accidentally beamed down into a distant space maze somewhere in the alien terrain. All you have to survive is a space suit, oxygen tank (with a limited oxygen supply), a compass and a map of the maze. You must make it to the exit of the maze before your oxygen supply runs out!

The game is a simple graphical 1st person maze game. Each move subtracts 1 from the total of your limited oxygen count.
title: 3D Maze

description:
You are thrown off course by a computer malfunction while cruising through space and encounter the evil Sistorian space fortress. You must battle your way through various deadly defence forces then attempt to destroy the space fortress before it puts up its shields and disappears into hyperspace.

Space Fortress is a Galaga type arcade style game where you can only move left or right and shoot. There are 20 skill levels, but you always start at skill level one. Each time you destroy the fortress you automatically advance to the next skill level. Each enemy ship is worth different values depending on enemy type, the Suicide Squad are worth 30, the Sidewinders are worth 40, the Sistorian Swoopers are worth 60, the Purple Avengers are worth 80 and the Space Fortress being worth 400 points. You begin with 5 lives and gain an extra life every time you destroy the space fortress, with a maximum of 9 lives. Rarely you may face a Super Alien that is almost impossible to kill, but you get points every time you hit it.
title: Space Fortress

description: Cosmic Cruncher is a Pac-Man variant. The player maneuvers their "Cosmic Cruncher" through the Milky Way in order to "crunch" all the pulsars in each part of the galaxy through eleven challenging levels. There are over 300 maze and color combinations to choose at the startup.

sample_screenshots.caption: A bonus item, in the shape of the Earth, appears at the top of the maze.
Pickup the space ships to be able to crunch the enemies.

title: Cosmic Cruncher

description: Fourth Encounter is a fixed screen shoot 'em up for one or two players. As the title might indicate it consists of four stages with different enemies in each. They can be played through in one go, or the player can pick any of them without completing the previous ones. The enemies in each stage have their own tactics in taking out the player. In the first wave the enemies try to crash into the player, while the aliens of the second and third stage fire at the player. The player ship can only move along the bottom and shoot up against the enemies. The fourth stage is the one that differs the most from the other stages. Here the enemies follow the edges of the screen and shoot in towards the player who now can move around the screen freely. What's more, it's also possible to shoot in two directions, both up and down. The player has five lives and it's game over when they are all lost. Three different skill levels can be chosen from.
title: Fourth Encounter

description:
Green on Black is a compilation of Commodore PET games ported to the VIC-20. It includes the following games:

  • Artillery
  • Atlantic Patrol
  • Voyage to Atlantis
  • PET Super Baseball
  • Bets
  • Casino Blackjack
  • Eliza
  • Flight Simulator
  • Island of Secrets
  • Journey to the Center of the Earth Adventure
  • Jumbo Jet Lander
  • Lemonade
  • Lunar Lander
  • Nuclear Power Plant
  • Ouranos!
  • Poker
  • Slot
  • Snark
  • Sorcerer's Castle Adventure
  • Hunt the Wumpus
title: Green on Black

description:
Beau Jolly bought the rights to Imagine's back catalogue when the company hit difficulties in 1984, and quickly released some of the world's first budget compilations based on their previous releases.

The VIC 20 compilation consists of six games:

  • Wacky Waiters
  • Arcadia* Catcha Snatcha
  • 3D Jumpin' Jack
  • Bewitched* Invaders
title: Beau Jolly VIC 20 Value Pack

description:
A freebie cassette given away with VIC 20s sold at the retail chain Canadian Tire. It contained 12 programs on two sides:

Side 1:

  • Introduction
  • VICman
  • Depth Charge
  • Rocket Command
  • Miniature Golf
  • Alien Waster

Side 2:

  • Tank Gunner
  • Dam Busters
  • Breakout
  • Star Chaser
  • Car Race
  • Tanks vs. UFO
title: Canadian Tire Complimentary Cassette

description: Space Math is an educational game where the player is the captain of the starship USS Victory. The ship is located on the right side of the screen and the player's job is to defend it from the missiles that are launched towards it from the left. Each missile has a math problem on it and to take them down the player has to type the correct answer before it reaches the starship. If successful the player earns some points and if not they are lost. Once the game is finished the player gets a positive or negative message depending on the score. It's possible to choose normal or fast speed and which of the four arithmetic operations to include.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting out - here comes the first missile

title: Space Math

description: Car Chase is a clone of the arcade game Head-On. It's a racing game played from a top down perspective where the player's car automatically moves forward on a circuit consisting of four lanes and the player can increase and decrease the speed as well as switching lanes at the middle of each straight. The player's job is to collect all the dots that lie scattered around but this is made hard by the jam cars that move in the player's opposite direction and attempt to intercept. The game is over after three collisions and a level is cleared once all dots have been collected. If the player is successful with clearing two levels and has less than ten dots left on the third, the dots will turn into diamonds when the AI car runs over them. These will then be worth extra points when collected.
title: Car Chase

description: Alien Blitz is a clone of Space Invaders with no noticeable differences in design and gameplay. The player moves his missile base left and right and has to shoot down the alien intruders that move back and forth above him. If they reach the base line or if the player loses all his three bases the game is over. Four shields offer some protection and at times a flying saucer will zap past the top of the screen. Before starting a game the player can choose a skill level from zero to nine.
title: Alien Blitz

description: Amok is a variant of Berzerk. Amok is also the name of a space station located far out in space that the player has to escape. Like in Berzerk, the player controls their character from a top down perspective and can move and shoot in multiple directions. Each room is inhabited by a number of robots that have run amok and are trying to kill the player. In addition to the robots, players also have to avoiding running into walls that will kill them upon contact. The robots have different colours (green, blue, red, black) that indicate how many points they are worth. Green are worth only five points while the black ones are worth 35. After scoring 1500 points, the player earns an extra life. The game consists of nine skill levels.
title: Amok

description: Alien Panic is a variant of Space Panic. Set in an abandoned construction site, the game is a single screen platformer where the player climbs ladders to move between the platforms while at the same time trying not to get killed by the aliens that roam about. The player can kill the aliens by digging holes which they then might fall into. When they do so the player quickly has to fill in the hole and bury the alien. If not quick enough, the alien will rise again. Once the aliens have been killed, the player moves on to the next level, of which there are six in total. When the game ends (after all three lives have been lost), the player gets a score based on how many aliens have been buried and how long it took.
title: Alien Panic

description: Abductor is a side view single screen shooter where you control a spacecraft at the bottom of the screen, moving left or right, and you have to blast and destroy all aliens that appear in various formations above. Below your craft are six humans and you must stop them being taken by swooping aliens to the top of the screen and if they reach the top, they turn into skulls and fall down the screen. If you are hit by an alien or falling skull then you lose one of three lives but if you lose all the humans then it is game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: The enemy will crash into you if you are not careful.

title: Abductor

description: Alien Soccer is a top view single screen paddle game where you must stop a ball that bounces around the screen, from going past your paddle. Your paddle is on the left of the screen and can move up or down and if the ball goes past then you lose one of five lives. Also on the screen are various aliens that are either static or move up or down and they deflect the ball when hit.

sample_screenshots.caption: Defend your goal and hit the aliens to score points.

title: Alien Soccer

description: Anti-Matter Splatter is a side view single screen shooter where you control a spacecraft at the bottom of the screen, moving left or right, and your mission is to protect humans below you, who are moving across the screen. At the top of the screen is an alien who drops bombs and the bombs have to be shot before they land and kill any human it touches. Between you and the alien are four platforms that move either left to right, or right to left and when shot destroys part of the platform. Any gaps allow the bombs to fall through but when a platform is completely destroyed it appears whole again. If you are hit by a bomb or all the humans are killed then it is game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: The blocks at the top of the screen can be destroyed by your weapon.
You must shoot the incoming bombs before they harm the humans at the bottom of the screen.
If you touch a bomb, your ship is destroyed.
As the game progresses, things get hectic with lots of bombs falling and few humans left alive.

title: Anti-Matter Splatter

description: Cosmonaut! is a single screen platform game where your spacecraft is trapped on the surface of a planet on the top of the screen and you need to free it to take-off. You must make your way down to the bottom of the screen to switch off a tractor beam and then make your way back to your craft. To move down the screen you must use elevators that move up or down in gaps in the platforms but once on an elevator you can jump off. There is a patrolling robot on the surface and various Stormtroopers that move along each platform and fire lasers at you. If you touch the robot, a Stormtrooper, get shot or fall through a gap then you lose one of five lives and start back on the surface.

sample_screenshots.caption: Made it to the bottom before being killed.

title: Cosmonaut!

description: Digger is a single screen game where you must dig around the screen through the dirt to kill various creatures that are digging and trying to kill you. As you move around the screen there are rocks and when the dirt is removed underneath then you can push the rock down to hopefully kill a creature. You are armed with a gun which stuns the creatures for a short time. If you are touched by a creature or crushed by a rock then it is game over.
title: Digger

description: Frantic is a 1st person shooter where you are being pulled by gravity downwards on a moon of the planet Spectrum. You have an anti-grav pack that allows you to stop mid-air, move left or right but you are unable to move upwards. As you fall there are many aliens moving around the area and you must blast them with your laser while avoiding getting shot by them. On the left and bottom of the screen are two radars which show the position of the aliens either above or below, and left or right of your position. Using your anti-grav pack and laser uses fuel which is shown by a gauge which decreases and when you run out of fuel then it is game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: Use the horizontal and vertical radar to home in on the enemies.
Each enemy is only worth one point.

title: Frantic

description:
A mad professor has planted a bomb in a sewer. You are trapped in his house and you have to escape it by collecting keys to open bars and get to the top of the screen, get through a jungle collecting keys to open the sewer and finally get down to the sewer, also collecting keys - but this time to defuse the bomb. The bomb will explode in a certain period of time, which the player can set at the beginning. 2 minutes, 2 minutes and 30 seconds, or 3 minutes.

In each level there are bonuses for the player to collect. Collecting these will award the player with extra points. Also each level has different hazards. The house level has turrets and lasers, the jungle has man-eating plants that are dangerous if they open their mouths, but harmless if their mouths are shut and there also falling coconuts and the sewer has vine-esque plants that will enlarge and shrink.

After the bomb is defused the game will start in the first level, the house level, again. Should the player not defuse the bomb in time the game will be over and the player can write his / her name for the high-score list.

sample_screenshots.caption: You must collect keys to open bars.

title: Countdown

description: Star Battle is a fixed-screen shoot'em-up based on Galaxian. The player controls a ship at the bottom of the screen that can be moved left or right while shooting aliens near the top of the screen. There are four types of alien ships (blue, purple, red and yellow) each with different advance (movement) speed and worth different points. With time the gameplay speeds up gradually and ships often swoop down to the bottom of the screen, attempting to crash into the player's ship. The ship has three lives and after destroying all enemies the game is restarted with the score kept. A red marker in the bottom right corner is added for each completed wave. The game supports two players, taking turns.

sample_screenshots.caption: The enemies become more aggressive as you progress.
Multiple ships will attack at the same time.
Aliens dive bomb your ship to try to destroy you.
Defeating all the aliens takes you to the next round.

title: Star Battle

description:
In Blitz an airplane moves across the screen at a constant speed. When the airplane reaches the far right of the screen it moves to the left-hand side and drops down the height of one airplane. Below the airplane is a number of skyscrapers of varying heights. The player has to drop bombs from the airplane by pressing the space bar. Each bomb can destroy six floors of the skyscraper it hits. As the plane descends, the airplane can crash into any remaining blocks, so the tallest skyscrapers should be targeted first. They can only be completed by destroying every floor of every building and then landing safely on the flattened ground.

The gameplay is extremely challenging, requiring excellent hand-to-eye coordination and near-perfect timing. It also offers very little margin for error and one missed opportunity will almost always end in failing a level. The game is unusual in that it requires the player to press only a single button to play - the space bar.

sample_screenshots.caption: Fail to destroy the buildings and your plane will crash into them.
Each round a new city is generated.
Drop bombs to destroy the buildings.
One crash and the game is over.

title: Blitz

description: In Rat Hotel the player takes control of a rat and has to eat cheese while not being caught by Waldo, a rat hating maintenance man. It takes place at Hotel Paradisio and on each of the hotel's floors the rat has to eat all pieces of cheese to be able to take the elevator to the next floor. At the same time it has to watch out for Waldo and the traps that he has placed all over the hotel. Any contact with Waldo or a trap will lead to one of three lives being lost but an extra one is granted after 10,000 points. There is a time limit too as the rat only has three minutes to move from the top to the bottom floor. The colour of the cheese changes over time and it's important to not eat it when it's black as this will paralyse the rat. However when it turns to blue it's worth double points compared to the orange one. Once the rat has eaten the big cheese in the basement the level has been completed and it will move on to a harder one. The difficulty level can also be chosen before starting the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting out at the top floor
Time is about to run out
Although it looks quiet, the guard will soon come after in the elevator
Once all cheese has been collected you can take the elevator to the next floor
It's not completely clear what all the objects actually are

title: Rat Hotel

description: Skibbereen is a Breakout game for two players (Pong with bricks is another way to describe it) based on Irish folklore. Each player uses a paddle to move a bat up and down and uses it to hit a ball. They both have a set of bricks to protect and behind them there is also a pot of gold that is worth extra when hit. The player that first destroys the opponent's bricks as well as pot of gold will win the game. But to complicate things, there are also snakes that at times enter the screen. These have to be avoided since hitting them three times will lead to a game over for both players. The game has nine difficulty levels which differ in the speed of the ball as well as the snakes. The game does not have any AI opponents so it cannot be played in single player (unless the player wants to control both paddles).

sample_screenshots.caption: Made a hole through to the pot
And it looks like we have a winner

title: Skibbereen

description:
In Catcha Snatch, the player takes the role of the store detective Barney Bootlace. He walks around the store, which is represented with one top-down screen, to do his job: guiding lost children back to their mom, bringing lost items to the lost property office, busting shoplifters and rushing bombs out of the door. Practically this boils down to touching the item/person in question and walking to the destination.

Barney's success is measured by his manager's approval from 0 to 99%. The approval rises when Barney manages to handle an issue correctly and decreases when he misses something. If 99% is reached, Barney is promoted to the next level (and a higher difficulty) - however, a demotion and a written warning follows directly after falling to 0%. After three warnings the game is over, but one warning is removed for advancing two levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: The store quickly becomes littered with items.
A shoplifter is escaping in the bottom right of the screen.

title: Catcha Snatcha

description: In Apple Bug, you control a bug who is trapped in a maze with a worm, and the object of the game is to eat all the apples on screen without coming into contact with the worm that chases you around the maze. If the worm catches you, the game is over. Movement is by keyboard only, and there are three skill levels to choose from.
title: Apple Bug

description: The object of the game is to climb the scaffolding to the top, collecting all the flags along the way, before the time runs out. A part of the scaffolding will drop to the ground and will crush you if you are in the way. There are also balloons that you can grab onto, that will allow you to float down to a platform below you. Movement is by keyboard only.

sample_screenshots.caption: A part of the scaffolding collapses
The keys you have to use in the game

title: Crazy Climber

description: In Demon Driver, the object is to race your car along a pre-defined track, running over cats to score points. If you come into contact with either side of the track, or are hit by barriers and boulders, the game ends. There are five skill levels, and movement is by keyboard only.
title: Demon Driver

description: You take control of a spaceship that must make its way across a landscape. As it progresses, its fuel supply will decrease, and you must either dock it or destroy the fuel bases on the surface. The game ends when the fuel supply runs out or if you collide with an object. Points are awarded when you fire at these objects, and you control the ship with the keyboard only.

sample_screenshots.caption: Press any key and get ready

title: Space Assault

description: In Jupiter Defender, the object is to move your ship across a landscape, killing aliens that approach it from the right with your built-in laser. The ship is also equipped with a number of bombs, which can be used to wipe out everything on screen. Coming into contact with the aliens results in a loss of life, and the game ends when all lives are lost.

sample_screenshots.caption: One of the aliens has fired a shot

title: Jupiter Defender

description:
Four Gates to Freedom consists of two parts: an action game and an adventure game. The action game has to be played first and after completing it the player is given a code that is needed to start the adventure game.

The game tells the story about a star cruiser that when exploring a far away planet is captured by a race of warrior ants. The crew and twenty scientists that were on board are drugged for future use as food for ants. The player's task is to destroy the four gates of the title and gain entry to the catacombs where the captives are held.

The action game is a fixed screen shoot'em up where the player controls a space craft down the bottom of the screen. Above there are a red and a blue wall that protects the four gates at the top of the screen. There are four levels and in each one several of the gates have to be destroyed but first a hole has to be blown through the walls. At the same time there are various enemies that can be shot (except one which has to be avoided). To make things harder enemies that are shot send out debris in multiple directions that can also kill the player.

The second game is a text adventure. The player enters directions (north, south etc.) to move around while interaction with the scenes is done by entering verbs such as go, take, use etc. Clues for the adventure game are given for each level completed in the action game.

sample_screenshots.caption: The white face is released when breaking down the first wall.

title: Four Gates to Freedom

description: The Catch is a single screen action game similar to the arcade game Avalanche. The player controls a force field over a number of cities and has to protect them by catching bombs that are dropped by an alien. The alien moves back and forth across the screen and the player has to follow it by moving left and right. The cities are destroyed as they are hit by bombs and the game goes on until there are no cities left to defend. The attacks come in waves with the speed of both the bombs and the alien increasing with each new stage.

sample_screenshots.caption: The alien moves back and forth and the player has to follow

title: The Catch

description: Escape is a maze game played from a first person perspective. Every time the game is loaded the game automatically generates a new maze. Before moving to the first person view the player gets to study the maze for a brief moment and can take note of its layout, the starting position and the exit. The player then navigates the maze by entering key commands based on the direction he wants to move in (n, s, e, w) and moves one step for each key press. To get a hint the player can show an overhead view by typing c (as in cheat). The game goes on until the player reaches the exit.

sample_screenshots.caption: First we see an overview of the maze (no title or loading screen)
Seeing the exit in the distance

title: Escape

description: Bomber is a Blitz variant with some changes made to the original game concept. Like before it is a one-button game where the player has to drop bombs from planes but instead of a city there is instead a canyon full of various objects that have to be hit. This version features three different aircraft that fly at different heights and appear from both sides of the screen. Unlike previous variants, the planes do not get progressively closer to the ground and cannot crash. Instead there is a time limit of two minutes and the player's task is simply to clear as much of the canyon as possible before time runs out. The game can be played with or without gravity. The difference is that with gravity bombs will clear more objects if they are dropped from a higher altitude while without gravity there is always only one object being destroyed.
title: Bomber

description: Blowup is a single screen action game where the player has to collect as many dots as possible. The game is played from a top down perspective and the screen consists of dots, black blocks that limit movement options and bombs that denote when the player touches them. The player's task is to move over the dots to collect the most of them and reach the exit before a timer reaches 3000. When it does the bombs will go off and the player will lose. The same happens when running into any of the bombs. The player controls an arrow that keeps moving until hitting a block or the player changes the direction. It leaves behind a blue trail when moving which turns green when moved over a second time. The player should avoid moving over it a second time since bonus points are given for each green section of the screen at the end of a level.

sample_screenshots.caption: Trail turns green when moving over it a second time

title: Blowup

description: Collide is a variant of the arcade game Head-On. Like the original game the player controls a car and has to collect all the dots on a race track that consists of four lanes. The car automatically moves forward counter-clockwise and an enemy (which here is a happy face) moves in the opposite direction trying to crash into the player. Changing lanes can only be done at intersections located in the middle of each straight. Hitting a divider when doing so will lead to the player losing control of the car for a short moment. The player has three cars and when they have all been crashed the game is over.

sample_screenshots.caption: Hitting a divider causes car to spin around

title: Collide

description:
Viva VIC is a compilation of eight Llamasoft titles for the VIC20:

  • Abductor
  • Andes Attack
  • Gridrunner
  • Hellgate
  • Matrix
  • Metagalactic Llamas: Battle at the Edge of Time
  • Traxx
title: Viva VIC

description:
Envahi is a side view fixed screen shoot 'em up where the player controls a helicopter and must defend a city that is being attacked by an invasion force. Next to the city is a large dam full of water that also has to be defended. The helicopter can be moved in all directions and shoots bullets upwards.

There are four different types of enemies to shoot down. Munchers move horizontally towards the dam and make holes in it upon reaching it. If the hole goes all the way through the water will flood the city. Nasties appear from a mothership at the top and move downwards until reaching a building. Slideys do the same but move faster and from side to side. Bully baliffs attempt to capture the helicopter and leave with it. Additionally the player has to watch out for rain drops since the helicopter is water soluble. A life is lost every time a building is captured, the helicopter crashes or the dam floods. Three lives are available at the start.
title: Envahi

description:
Wunda Walter! is a fast-paced side-scrolling action game where the player controls a balloon-like character called Walter. The game takes place on the planet Plato where venomous energies called fuzz-balls have created chaos. It is up to Walter to eliminate these things by simply stepping on them.

Walter starts out running on the ground and by holding the joystick button he will rise up in the air. Releasing it again will cause him to fall back towards the ground. The aim of the game is simply to make it across the levels while stepping on as many fuzz-balls as possible. The difficulty of the game comes from the various dangerous objects and rough surfaces that have to be avoided. Any contact with these will cause Walter to burst. Walter has five lives and when they are used up it's game over. There are four levels with different landscapes and obstacles.
title: Wunda Walter!

description: Ludwig's Lemon Lasers is a simple shoot 'em up game where the player has to shoot down as many lemons as possible. The player controls an automatically firing laser gun that can be moved up and down along the right edge of the screen. An endless amount of lemons appear from the left and move towards the player's location. If a lemon makes it all the way to the right the game ends and the player gets a score.
